nbtedly grant the State lands lying along the contemplated
0f road, of which she possesses a large amount, to build
road. Texas for her part will make similar grants to a
Iberal amount, and also appropriate largely of her cash
eans and Congress is relied on with confidence, for grants
nfthe public lands towards the enterprise, Such grants have

• fljis road, as in the case of the Illinois Central Railroad,
where the lands granted have been found sufficient alone to

The last mail from California brings intelligence that it is
proposed, and generally advocated there, to petition Con-
gress,(and their senators and representatives will be instructed to support the measure,) to appropriate part ofthe proceeds
of the mineral lands to construct a railroad from the Pacific
to the Atlantic by way of EI Passo, the very line of road under consideration.
The whole country must be favorable to a road which will
stretch from ocean to ocean, and bind together this great Republic, far more effectively than statutes or constitutions can
do.
The South is particularly interested in its completion ; for
it will afford her efficient means of securing from the North
respectfor her institutions. The road must become the great
highway from the Eastern to the Western Ocean, and over
this highway, and through our territory, the people of the
Brth must pass with their merchandise, to reach the modern
land of Ophir, and to reap the golden harvest of its trade ;
and the South may demand ofthe north, as toll, unconditional respect for her rights, and depend upon it the tribute will
be paid.
"y order of the Executive Committee,
M. M. COHEN, Chaieman.
"■ •*■ Flanders, Secretary.
